<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketRecvFrom:
```c
int32 OS_SocketRecvFrom(osal_id_t sock_id, void *buffer, size_t buflen, OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /*
     * Check parameters
     *
     * Note "RemoteAddr" is not checked, because in certain configurations it can be validly null.
     */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
        {
            /* Socket needs to be bound first */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketRecvFrom_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr, timeout);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```

int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The controlling expression uses the runtime field stream->stream_state masked with the constant OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND. stream is obtained from the OS_stream_table (an array of mutable records), so stream->stream_state is not a compile-time invariant; the condition can evaluate differently at runtime depending on the socket state. Therefore Rule 14.3 is not violated.
